intro: Asperula cynanchica var. exaristata, commonly known as the hairy woodbine, is a deciduous climbing vine native to the eastern United States. It features slender, woody stems that are covered in fine, hairy hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically white or pale blue, blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and have a soft, hairy texture. Asperula cynanchica var. exaristata is often found in woodland edges and moist, shaded areas, where it thrives in partial to full shade.
